awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal:  MSA:  Controls on coupled nitrogen and carbon cycles of watersheds across eco-regions
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Collaborative Proposal: MSA: Controls on coupled nitrogen and carbon cycles of watersheds across eco-regions

Nitrogen is a critical nutrient that supports life.  Too much can cause problems such as unsightly algal blooms or coastal dead zones where fish cannot live.  The fate of nitrogen is closely tied to the fate of carbon in plants and soil.  However, the connection between nitrogen and carbon remains poorly understood.  In particular, little is known about carbon and nitrogen interactions across different landscapes, from the tropics to the arctic.  This project will help better understand what controls nitrogen leaving watersheds through streams.  It will take advantage of data collected by the National Ecological Observatory Network across the nation's diverse environments.  This research is important as people add more nitrogen to the land through air pollution, fertilizers, and septic systems.  It will also help understand how much carbon the environment can absorb as carbon dioxide increases in the atmosphere.  The project will result in new data sets that will be shared with other researchers.  The project team will work with schools and local communities to explain how what happens on land affects water quality.  Findings will be translated to be useful for policy makers.  A diverse group of students will learn how to use environmental sensor technology. 

Consistent input and output measurements for terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems collected by NEON will be used to address the overarching question: "How tightly are watershed carbon (C) and nitrogen (N) cycles coupled across biomes and how is this coupling influenced by physical environmental conditions (climate and hydrology), vegetation characteristics, and legacies from past disturbance?" Hypotheses will be tested related to the role of watershed carbon to nitrogen ratios, precipitation, storminess, temperature, and disturbance using 1) ongoing NEON sensor, manually-collected, and remote sensing measurements to estimate watershed N inputs, N outputs and net ecosystem C exchange (NEE), 2) a terrestrial ecosystem model (PnET) to scale NEE to the entire watershed draining to streams, and 3) analysis of watershed net N and C fluxes against potential explanatory data for each domain. Twenty-two NEON watersheds defined by wadeable streams and proximity of NEE measurements will be used, incorporating a wide range of watershed characteristics.  Watershed budget estimates will include estimates of uncertainty in both C and N fluxes and sinks. Scientific findings will be translated into education and policy relevant information with groups such as LTER Schoolyard program and the Science Policy Exchange.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Terrestrial carbon and nitrogen cycles are strongly linked through plant activity.  This linkage influences both how much anthropogenic carbon in the atmosphere can be stored by terrestrial ecosystem, and important carbon sink, as well as how much nitrogen is released to sensitive surface waters and coastal regions where it can lead to harmful algal blooms and eutrophication.  Most of the nitrogen used in natural ecosystems is provided by the decomposition of organic matter and its uptake and (re)-use by plants. However, increased fertilizer use and nitrogen deposition have increased nitrogen fluxes between terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems.

Increasing atmospheric CO2 concentrations can lead to increases in plant photosynthesis. This increase in photosynthesis requires more nitrogen, or leads to a change in the chemical composition of plant tissues – namely increasing their carbon to nitrogen (C:N) ratios. Plant C:N ratios are of particular interest because they strongly control decomposition rates and therefore nitrogen cycling, which can propagate through soils to groundwater and eventually to streams. Using data from the National Ecological Observation Network (NEON), we assessed how C:N ratios vary across a continental scale, from tropical Puerto Rico to tundra Alaska, and throughout a watershed, from plants to soils to water, and how C:N ratios affect nitrogen retention.

Our analysis shows that sites with high plant C:N ratios also have high soil and water C:N, demonstrating the interconnectedness of the different pools in a watershed. We also found that large scale environmental properties, namely precipitation and soil pH, affect how C:N ratios change from plants to soils to water: more acidic and wetter sites tend to have C:N that remains higher throughout the watershed – decomposition is slower under these conditions meaning that organic matter conserves its chemical signature for longer. We did not, however, find any strong relationships between watershed nitrogen balances (inputs from precipitation and stream exports) and C:N of plants or soils, or C:N changes through the watershed. While we did not find a direct relationship between nitrogen budgets and C:N ratios, we did find that changes to plant C:N are likely to cascade down to water, but both elements need to be considered conjointly instead of individually. This study was one of the first to be able to conduct large-scale analyses of the linked terrestrial and aquatic carbon and nitrogen cycle, largely due to NEON’s infrastructure.

Broader impacts:

This project supported the work of one PhD student and two undergraduate researchers, both of whom are pursuing master’s degrees in the field. The workflows produced here to analyze NEON data will be made publicly available through GitHub. We hope that these will be repurposed for future work with NEON data, especially important to allow NEON to track changes over time. In tandem with this work, we have been working on a project analyzing the human dimensions of macrosystems ecology.  This project uses cartography to explore how different people interact with NEON sites – from indigenous groups that lived on the land today, to technicians who analyze samples in national labs or researchers who use the data without necessarily visiting the sites or even their biome. The goal of this work is to spark conversation about how these spatial disparities may affect our understanding of how different ecosystems behave.
